author: Derek
title: Fireworks in D.C. Ahead of July 4th Fireworks
content: Fireworks were set off in Washington D.C. on Monday as President Trump tweeted that he would ban electric scooters, smiley emojis, and happiness, in what many critics are calling a step too far.

author: Derek
title: Why You Should Learn To Code
content: Coding is a difficult and rewarding career path.

author: Derek
title: 'COEXIST' Bumper Sticker Stops Suicide Bombing In Kabul
content:
KABUL, AFGHANISTAN — On Friday morning, a suicide bombing attempt was stopped dead in its tracks by a \“COEXIST\” bumper sticker in streets of the capital city of Afghanistan.  A parked car sporting the trendy decal was seen by an ISIS fighter who caught a glimpse, ultimately reconsidering his behavior. 
 
 Abdul Muhsin, a 10-year terrorist veteran, was seen quietly removing his suicide vest outside of the U.S. embassy after spotting the car.   Abdul waited for twenty minutes at the scene to thank the owner of the car for changing his life. 
 
  Abdul later invited the owner of the car, Muhammad Shaheed, to join him for an iced latte to discuss how diplomacy can be used to bring people together. 
 
 \”I was going down a dark path.  Now that I look back at it, I cant believe what a monster I had become,\” said Abdul of the reformation. 
 
 In light of the event, security forces outside of the U.S. Embassy in Kabul have ramped up security measures by ordering thousands of coexist bumper stickers today.  The hope is that the stickers will continue to deter violence, acting as yet another layer of security in the war torn nation. 
 
 US Army Col. James Hoover said, \”we hope to saturate the streets of Kabul with these bumper stickers.  Ultimately, we need to have one on every car if we hope to keep this violence at bay.  Deterrence is half the battle.\”

author: Zach
title: Software Engineering Immersive: The Great Balancing Act
content:
You can learn a lot about yourself when you spend your time dedicated to a singular cause. After having just finished my fifth week of a 12-week software engineering immersive course, I can confidently say that I like who I am today more than I did before stepping in the door five weeks ago. The students in my cohort come from a variety of backgrounds with different stories to tell. Our common bond comes through varying degrees of dissatisfaction for our previous work encounters combined with an urge to master material that we can truly put our name and passion behind. Software engineering, or programming in general, is not a field meant for every type of mindset. However, during my experience, I have found that even the toughest days are more enjoyable than other types of work. The \“flow\” losing track of time due to intense focus that I have experienced rivals few other things that I have experienced. Even during times that I cannot figure out a certain bug in my code, the feeling is less of frustration than it is of embracing a challenge that has not been solved yet. 
 
 I think that it is unrealistic to be asked to shut down your entire social network during this 12-week period, and I think that even people who tell you to or claim that they have themselves while taking the course are not telling the truth. Nevertheless, certain adjustments have to be made, and for me that has been trimming around the edges. For someone who strives to jump into the tech field, I have substantially cut down on my screen usages, going through specific measures to ensure that my distractions are kept to a minimum. I have turned off all of the notifications on my phone, delete many distracting apps, hid toolbars on the computer, and took other measures in order to keep my mind focused on the task at hand, rather than having my subconscious take the best of my attention. While I am still thinking of measures to take in order to narrow my focus, I have found that specific changes are much more effective than simply telling yourself to do something different. 
 
 Feeling good and being excited about the material to come is most of the battle, and for the most part they both work hand in hand. Making sure that I am properly nourished, caught up on sleep, and in a general good state of mind are all crucial toward being excited about the material, or at least putting myself in the best position to do well. While they are normal reactions for all humans to have, negativeness, complaining, and deflecting problems off oneself all fall short of accomplishing any goal currently at hand. 
 
 While we are certainly embarking part of the most challenging material of the class to date, it is crucial to stay positive, stay active, and take the small wins when they come. For me, I sometimes put myself in a questioning mindset of why I am not picking up on certain subjects more easily. However, learning four year’s worth of software engineering in 12 weeks is a daunting task no matter who decided to pick up the class, and giving yourself a break is one of the easiest fixes. 
 
 I am excited to finish the second half of this class with the same amount of intensity that it began with. I truly feel that the class is a no-judgment zone, where people are not afraid to admit that they have not grasped a particular subject, making it that much easier to receive help where it is needed. It is an amazing feeling to know that I have learned something new and am getting smarter every day, something that cannot be said when in the wrong type of environment.

author: Kirran
title: What your personality type says about where you belong in tech…
content:
When people begin to consider getting into the tech industry, they are soon confronted by the dilemma of which role they would suit them best. People typically begin by choosing between designer and developer, as the market for both is rapidly growing. In order to choose, the first step would obviously be to find out what each role involves to get a general idea where you may fit, but that is not sufficient enough to make a long term decision. You will likely end up burning out quicker than others if you made the wrong pick for a myriad of reasons. This begs the question… What other precautions can we take to make a more educated decision about our selected role? I would offer that personality type can be a great indicator of where you fit as it can provide you with an understanding of your psychological leanings and rhythms. There are, of course, those who fit into both roles comfortably — however, we typically refer to those people as unicorns due to how rare those people are. If we’re starting with personality type, this begs the question, \“how does one know their personality type?\” 
 
 To investigate our own personalities, the most efficient method would be to use a personality test… But which one? There are many different personality tests, some great and some not so great. The earliest and most reputable personality test was created by Carl Jung, who coined the term Enneagram as its name. The enneagram divided personality types into 9 categories that were simply named according to number, so you could be a \“type 1\” and so on, all the way to type 9. Nowadays the most common personality test is known as the 16 personalities test which is based on the Myers Briggs test, which was also based on Jungian psychological principles. The 16 personality test breaks down personality into four categories: introversion vs extroversion/intuitiveness vs sensory adeptness/feeling vs thinking and judgement vs perception, allowing for a total of 16 unique personality types. Using these type distinctions, one can begin to make an educated guess as to where a given individual may fit in a given industry.  Breaking it down, let us start with the analysis of introversion vs extroversion in tech. Intuition may guide you to assume that the tech industry is only fit for introverts, as it requires long hours of working through complex problems independently, however, there is more nuance involved. Introversion (I) best facilitates a problem solving heavy role when its paired with a strong thinking function (T), but not all introverts are T dominant! Some are feeling (F) dominant and would be more comfortable in other roles like UX design. An introvert with an affinity for feeling typically possess strong empathy skills and make great candidates for understanding the needs and feelings of their users.  Next, sensing versus intuition. Someone who is a sensing type is primarily concerned with sensory stimuli and focus on what is present and what is real. They like to focus on minor details first and then the bigger picture after.  
 
 Conversely, intuitive types are primarily concerned with symbols abstract theories and impressions and like to focus on the bigger picture first, before figuring out the smaller pieces. Given this, we can make the assumption that sensory dominant people would be better suited in rolls that involve solving problems from the ground up, i.e. developer roles, where they can use their meticulousness to their advantage in attempting to solve complex problems. Alternatively, intuitive types would be better suited in design roles where they can work with more abstract constructs like color, space, and understanding other people’s outlook. 
 
  Finally, judgment vs perception. Perceptive types like spontaneity, flexibility, and change, whereas judgment types like order and routine. These types are more flexibly related to any particular field. One can make the assumption that perceptive types are better suited to be fit into a design field due to liking spontaneity, but there can easily be as much spontaneity in a developer role due to a rapidly changing project landscape that is characteristic of agencies.  Don’t let your personality type sway you away from any field. If you are truly passionate about a field, that matters more than anything else. Personality is an infinitely complex field and human beings are not a predictable species. But it can be useful to understand what fits your personality best in order to make more accurate assessments in figuring out our long term goals.
